B000JBXXZ4|3.0|Not too many artists around Incubus time are still alive and making interesting music. The whole wave of music from the late nineties is pretty much dead and/or extinct, save for a few small tours in towns with odd demographics and few transistor radios. There's a certain reverie for that type of accomplishment and Incubus deserves some merit.<br /><br />After what would seem like their peak with A Crow Left of the Murder, Brandon Boyd and his team of wavy styled musicians managed to carve up some decent tunes. Decent is such a bland word, but to be honest, it might work well here.<br /><br />For starters, songs \\"Anna Molly\\" and \\"Dig\\" (which happen to be the album's first singles) are the only tunes to really chalk up some life that seems to be reincarnated over and over again for most of the album's fillings. To say, \\"I'm waiting for these songs to grow on me\\" would be an understatement and to be quite honest, a thing of the past.<br /><br />\\"Light Grenades\\", the album's title track, sounds like something off of S.C.I.E.N.C.E. without the catchy riff raff that iced over past songs, \\"Vitamin\\" and \\"New Skin.\\" Meanwhile, I'm still trying to wrap my head around the annoying and bombastic, \\"Earth to Bella\\", which unfortunately is in two parts. Boyd's vocals, from start to finish, in this number come off as annoying and repetitive.<br /><br />However, \\"Pendulous Threads\\" is like swimming in the water to guitarist Mike Einziger's staple sound. Aquatic scales and affluent basslines really make out a killer tune that no doubtly sounds exceptional on any subwoofer. This is a track that is inherently a better live performance in the making and probably Incubus first driving fist in a long while.<br /><br />Influence or not, this album has some heavy Police undertones which should make any album worthwhile. Unfortunately, several of the songs are plagued with lyrics that are either forced or juvenile, especially in contrast to Boyd's previous works. One good example of this is in \\"Paper Shoes\\" which starts off fresh, albeit sounding musically like a Pearl Jam tune, but eventually drags on and on with the lyrics going nowhere.(This is the same guy who wrote \\"Sick Sad Little World\\" and \\"A Certain Shade of Green\\"?) It's disappointing considering Boyd is one of the best frontman and vocalists today.<br /><br />With all the negativity, then why the three stars?<br /><br />Songs like \\"Dig\\", \\"Anna Molly\\", the ultimately catchy \\"Love Hurts\\", the rocking \\"Pendulous Threads\\", and the very A Crow Left of the Murder-esque \\"Rogues\\" make the album worth the wait and memorable at the very least. Nevertheless, songs \\"Earth to Bella 1 and 2\\", \\"Light Grenades\\", and \\"A Kiss To Send Us Off\\" are still ultimately disappointing.<br /><br />Is Light Grenades the follow up everyone has been waiting for since 2004? Perhaps. There is some growth in the songs, but not by much... which is usually a good thing. But, for some tracks, a few might be indistinguishable to their previous efforts which may lend light to why those few are actually catchy.<br /><br />In the end, I'd still much rather listen to A Crow Left of the Murder, but who knows? Morning View eventually grew on me, maybe this will. Call me a hipocrite, but I'll be at their first show.resh, albeit sounding musically like a Pearl Jam tune, but eventually drags on and on with the lyrics going nowhere.(This is the same guy who wrote \\"Sick Sad Little World\\" and \\"A Certain Shade of Green\\"?) It's disappointing considering Boyd is one of the best frontman and vocalists today.     With all the negativity, then why the three stars?     Songs like \\"Dig\\", \\"Anna Molly\\", the ultimately catchy \\"Love Hurts\\", the rocking \\"Pendulous Threads\\", and the very A Crow Left of the Murder-esque \\"Rogues\\" make the album worth the wait and memorable at the very least. Nevertheless, songs \\"Earth to Bella 1 and 2\\", \\"Light Grenades\\", and \\"A Kiss To Send Us Off\\" are still ultimately disappointing.    Is Light Grenades the follow up everyone has been waiting for since 2004? Perhaps. There is some growth in the songs, but not by much... which is usually a good thing. But, for some tracks, a few might be indistinguishable to their previous efforts which may lend light to why those few are actually catchy.     In the end, I'd still much rather listen to A Crow Left of the Murder, but who knows? Morning View eventually grew on me, maybe this will. Call me a hipocrite, but I'll be at their first show.

So, I have knowledge on the movies. <br /> <br />Superman Returns pays homage, not only to the Richard Donner's Superman and Superman II (cruelly credited to Rick Lester), but, also to Christopher Reeve and Margot Kidder.  I found it quite easy to believe Brandon Routh as Superman because he looks so much like Christopher Reeve and his acting was actually pretty good.  I also accepted the fact that it was not Reeve I was watching, but, another actor picking up where Reeve left off (hint, hint).  It was also easy to figure out where Superman Returns actually take place.  I must admit that I first thought that it took place after Superman IV.  But, I remembered that in Superman IV, Clark Kent's mother had passed away.  So, I had to go back and realize that it took place right between II and III.  Having accepted that knowledge, I began to appreciate the film a lot more than I already did.   <br /> <br />The visuals are stunning.  The plot is fantastic.  The casting is great.  The only problem I have with the film is Superman's costume.  I wish the costume was brighter.  However, that's bearable because there's more to movies than special effects and costumes.  The acting, the visuals, the plot, etc. are fantastic and I can't wait to see what Bryan Singer and Brandon have to offer in the next Superman movies. <br /> <br />Buy this film.  It is, indeed a classic and a respectable homage to Richard Donner and Christopher Reeve.  It's also a great homage to Marlon Brandon as he makes a posthumous appearance as Jor-El in this wonderful film. <br /> <br />And to the people who complain about the film retreading old territory:  remember that the last Superman MOVIE was made almost twenty years ago.  I'm sure the director and writers made a conscious effort to make us (those who saw the other movies) remember what happened as well as educate all the new-comers on Superman's \\"movie history\\".  GET OVER IT or watch something else.

B00008973Q|3.0|Akira Kurosawa's Ran, is an adaptation of Shakespeare's King Lear, set in sixteenth century Japan.  Ran is the story of Great Lord Hidetora who has decided to step down and allow his three sons to rule, Taro, Jiro and Saburo, on the condition that he could live with them in turns as a guest.  The youngest son, Saburo tries to tell his father of the folly in this plan, doubting that all three sons would unite peacefully.  Hidetora is angered by Saburo's attempts to warn him and exiles him from the kingdom.  The oldest son, Taro, his wife Su, whose family had been killed by Hidetora, and Jiro, scheme to take complete control away from Hidetora and drive him from the kingdom, and then they turn on each other for power.  Hidetora is driven mad by all of this, tended only by a faithful friend and the court jester.  Eventually Hidetora is brought to Saburo, who despite exile, helps his father.  The movie is slow and drawn out at times, but it is an epic tale of greed and the desire for power.  The fate of Hidetora is determined by those who he wronged in the past.

B000000OUJ|5.0|GZA's debut solo album \\"Liquid Swords\\" is an undeniable classic. The album is of the first wave of Wu-Tang solos from 1994-1996 following the legendary group album \\"Enter the Wu-Tang: 36 Chambers.\\" On that album, GZA was shown to maybe the group's best lyricist, a metaphorical master who lived up to his nickname of \\"the genius.\\" This album boasts multiple classic tracks, and it's got such a great feeling. The dark, gritty production gives it a cinematic feel, which is heightened by the dramatic kung-fu movie samples throughout the album. RZA handles the productive and it is awesome, completely fitting of GZA's amazing lyrics. The production is very similar to \\"36 Chambers,\\" RZA showing his signature style on the mixing boards. This album is only 13 tracks, but the tracks are all complete and it's a perfect length, not at all overblown like some later Wu releases would be. Almost the entire Wu-Tang Clan makes a guest appearance at some point on the album, so it's a group effort in some respects, but GZA always shines. Lyrically he is a beast, and this album may be his shining triumph. He uses battle-type rhymes often, full of great punchlines and also uses a lot of metaphors. He stays very true to the original Wu-Tang style though, often referencing kung-fu and chess in his rhymes. \\"Liquid Swords\\" is in my opinion the best Wu-Tang solo and a classic album, necessary for any fan of 90s hip hop or Wu.<br /><br />The album begins with the title track, which has a great organ-laced beat and GZA displays his addictive flow and nasal voice, shooting lyrical bullets. \\"Duel of the Iron Mic\\" is hard-hitting and well-produced by RZA. \\"Living in the World Today\\" is musically simple and lyrically complex, GZA boasts of Wu-Tang's prominence and is full of punchlines. \\"Gold\\" is an almost mafioso look at his lifestyle. \\"Cold World\\" has an awesome, almost disturbing chorus and GZA takes the opportunity for great storytelling. \\"Labels\\" is very clever, he uses all the record label names he can think of to almost make fun of them, I like this song a lot. \\"4th Chamber\\" is one of my favorites on the disc, it has an awesome beat and great verses from the Genius and Ghostface Killah, this is a Wu-Tang classic like the other \\"Chamber\\" cuts of old. \\"Shadowboxin'\\" is another classic, a collaboration with Method Man where the duo slays MCs with their Shaolin styles. \\"Killah Hills 10304\\" is another simply awesome song preluded by a funny interlude. \\"Investigative Reports\\" is so cool to listen to, GZA tells a paranoid view of the world and crime life. \\"Swordsman\\" is a metaphor-heavy representative track of his character, and \\"I Gotcha Back\\" is another of my favorites, GZA telling an eerie philosophy (\\"I gotcha back, but you'd best a-watch your front / `cause it's them n....s in front, they be pullin' stunts\\"). The last song is my absolute favorite, \\"Basic Instructions Before Leaving Earth.\\" This track is completely unlike any other on the album, so it's good that it was last on the album. It's a very conscious and relevant song by Killah Priest that tackles racial and religious disunity, looking to the children of the world and trying to find peace. The beat has an awesome, relaxing sample and a great vocal sample. I love the hook, this song just ends the album perfectly.<br /><br />\\"Liquid Swords\\" is a complete, well-rounded, and diverse masterpiece, unique and basically unlike any other album I have heard. Even among the Wu-Tang classics it shines as a legendary work, one that would never again be matched by GZA. This is one of those albums that I find something new I like about it every time, and I really don't find that in many albums that are released today. I strongly recommend the purchase of \\"Liquid Swords\\" to all passing hip hop fans, this is even one of those albums that could sell rap to a non fan. This is one of the essential albums that built the legend of the Wu-Tang Clan.n think of to almost make fun of them, I like this song a lot. \\"4th Chamber\\" is one of my favorites on the disc, it has an awesome beat and great verses from the Genius and Ghostface Killah, this is a Wu-Tang classic like the other \\"Chamber\\" cuts of old. \\"Shadowboxin'\\" is another classic, a collaboration with Method Man where the duo slays MCs with their Shaolin styles. \\"Killah Hills 10304\\" is another simply awesome song preluded by a funny interlude. \\"Investigative Reports\\" is so cool to listen to, GZA tells a paranoid view of the world and crime life. \\"Swordsman\\" is a metaphor-heavy representative track of his character, and \\"I Gotcha Back\\" is another of my favorites, GZA telling an eerie philosophy (\\"I gotcha back, but you'd best a-watch your front / `cause it's them n....s in front, they be pullin' stunts\\"). The last song is my absolute favorite, \\"Basic Instructions Before Leaving Earth.\\" This track is completely unlike any other on the album, so it's good that it was last on the album. It's a very conscious and relevant song by Killah Priest that tackles racial and religious disunity, looking to the children of the world and trying to find peace. The beat has an awesome, relaxing sample and a great vocal sample. I love the hook, this song just ends the album perfectly.    \\"Liquid Swords\\" is a complete, well-rounded, and diverse masterpiece, unique and basically unlike any other album I have heard. Even among the Wu-Tang classics it shines as a legendary work, one that would never again be matched by GZA. This is one of those albums that I find something new I like about it every time, and I really don't find that in many albums that are released today. I strongly recommend the purchase of \\"Liquid Swords\\" to all passing hip hop fans, this is even one of those albums that could sell rap to a non fan. This is one of the essential albums that built the legend of the Wu-Tang Clan.
B00005JPCA|5.0|I am a big Bond fanatic and had huge reservations about Daniel Craig taking over the 007 role.  Casino Royale is my favorite of the Flemming novels [edging out Thunderball], so I have been waiting anxiously for a proper film treatment of the introductory story in the Bond canon, which made me all the more nervous about seeing the blonde Bond take the licence from Pierce Brosnan.  Well, mission accomplished.  Craig turns out to be the perfect blend of rough around the edges in the movie's opening third and then grows perfectly into the sort of Bond that we're used to seeing as the character is promoted and eases into his new slate as a 'double-o'.  The story is similar to the original novel, with Bond having to outwit LeChifre at a casino, though character names and some details of the actual characters are updated and shuffled to account for modern political situations.  The action sequences that begin and end the movie are spectacular, whereas the middle portion is where the character does the most developing as an espionage agent  This is a very long film by Bond standards, but it only drags a little near the end before picking back up again.  My trepidations were unfounded as Craig and company pull off the story and add to the fledgling franchise quite nicely.  The omages and nods to the series' long past are especially well done [variations on the vodka martini, Bond's preference to married women and his favored choice of vehicle].  The title sequence and accompaning song are superb [regrettably the main title does not appear on the movie soundtrack].    Add note; the second viewing was even more enjoyable as I was able to catch more the second time around.

B000JK8OYU|3.0|One of the most eagerly awaited releases of the year?  Well, maybe for a Beatles fan.  To be fair to Mr. Martin, the Love CD is a mixed bag of revelations.  I was under the impression that the original intent of this project was to present the music of the Beatles in a new light--the same way Zappa was doing (and his estate currently is) with his music:  remixing different snippets to make whole new songs.  When the father and son team of Martin actually sets out to do this, the results are nothing short of revelatory.  You need only to hear the \\"Within You Without You/Tomorrow Never Knows\\" sequence to see this.  Other highlights:  Drive My Car/The Word/What You're Doing-inserting the Taxman guitar solo right in the middle was brilliant; \\"Strawberry Fields Forever\\" sounds like someone having a nervous breakdown; \\"Get Back\\" is reworked with that awesome drum solo from \\"Oh Yeah\\" on the Abbey Road album.   For the most part, the rest of the music seemed to be remixes whose sound quality, though much improved, was not that much different from the original fare.  Sure there are snippets thrown on at the end of some songs that make for some creative transitions, but these parts seem more like afterthoughts put in at the last minute to meet the obligatory standards that had been laid out in the advertisement of this disc in the first place.  In short, the CD is still a worthwhile purchase, if for nothing else the improved sound quality, but don't expect a comeplete retooling of the classics.
B000FTWB7G|4.0|Evanescence has been through a lot since its major label debut \\"Fallen\\" rocked the charts in 2003. Songwriter/guitarist Ben Moody departed from the band on account of personal and creative differences with lead singer Amy Lee and has since moved on to work with other artists (Avril Lavigne, Kelly Clarkson), and Lee herself has been at the heart of a well-publicized sexual harassment lawsuit. At long last, however, the band's long-anticipated \\"The Open Door\\" has arrived, having debuted at #1 on the Billboard charts.<br /><br />While Lee is flanked by talented musicians, she is now the indisputable centerpiece of the band, which was inevitable from the beginning. She wrote all the tracks either solo or in tandem with the band's new guitarist, Terry Balsamo, and staking a clear assertion of independence. From her impassioned vocals to her forthright lyrics, it is clear to see she has a lot to get off her chest.<br /><br />Lead single \\"Call Me When You're Sober\\" seems at once like yet another Kelly Clarkson radio hit, but this actually works well, striding the line between catchy pop and mainstream rock. Constant airplay has not diluted the song's appeal as it continues to air out Lee's frustrations with Shaun Morgan, her ex-boyfriend and lead singer of rock band Seether. \\"Lithium,\\" the second single, channels Sarah McLachlan with piano/vocal simplicity before the guitar riffs surge, beckoning the psychiatrist's couch with its deep, dark gloom.<br /><br />The album's opening track, \\"Sweet Sacrifice,\\" however, is extremely radio friendly, with a downright awesome hook and sharp lyrics to boot. Meanwhile, the lower-key duo of \\"Your Star\\" and \\"Like You\\" ruminates with such cryptic observations (\\"I'd like to be like you/Lie cold in the ground like you\\") that comparisons to the psyche of Emily Dickinson would be justified.<br /><br />Elsewhere, \\"Weight of the World\\" paves the path for a new future, finding Lee declaring \\"I won't be held down by who I used to be,\\" while \\"Snow White Queen\\" recounts sexual abuse.<br /><br />\\"You belong to me/My snow white queen/There's nowhere to run, so lets just get it over/Soon I know you'll see/You're just like me/Don't scream anymore my love, `cause all I want is you.\\"<br /><br />The album concludes starkly with \\"Good Enough,\\" finding Lee at her most vulnerable as she puts her guard down, declaring \\"I've completely lost myself and I don't mind/I can't say no to you.\\"<br /><br />Listeners who enjoyed \\"Fallen\\" will by more than pleased with \\"The Open Door.\\" The songwriting might not be as refined with Lee steering the ship almost entirely on her own, but she more than compensates for it with ardor and artistic devotion.abuse.    \\"You belong to me/My snow white queen/There's nowhere to run, so lets just get it over/Soon I know you'll see/You're just like me/Don't scream anymore my love, `cause all I want is you.\\"    The album concludes starkly with \\"Good Enough,\\" finding Lee at her most vulnerable as she puts her guard down, declaring \\"I've completely lost myself and I don't mind/I can't say no to you.\\"    Listeners who enjoyed \\"Fallen\\" will by more than pleased with \\"The Open Door.\\" The songwriting might not be as refined with Lee steering the ship almost entirely on her own, but she more than compensates for it with ardor and artistic devotion.

I was informed if I liked Coldplay and Radiohead, I would like this. Every song is impeccable.  <br /> <br />The piano/drums/vocal dynamic is capable of being lush and intimate at the same time, which helps connect the listener to the music on a personal level. Chaplin's voice is surreal, almost other-worldly to me. I don't get why all the singers today insist on falsetto (especially when most of them sound like kazoos when they get too high), but Chaplin really does sound beautiful up there in the stratosphere and he helps bring these already good songs up to the level of greatness. The lyrics are at once melancholy but then uplifting and all the moods are facilitated by lofting choruses and melodies.  <br /> <br />After doubting them for so long, I now stand corrected, and this album has become one of my true favorites. <br />

I also won't go into any spoilers since you can also read that from other reviews and online fan sites. We finally learn what happened to Clark that allowed him to get his powers back. But one thing is for certain.  The Donner Cut is a far deeper \\"Superman II\\" and far exemplifies why Christopher Reeve will always be our SUPERMAN!

B000HIVQK8|4.0|This is one of George's finest albums, and was released when his stock was really high, following the tremendous success of All Things Must Pass and the benefit concert for Bangla Desh.  In that context, this album was a bit of a letdown.  It lacked the grandeur and backlog of songs that ATMP had; and it likewise lacked the star power of Bangla Desh.  All these years later, it plays like one his most confident albums.  The success of his career up until that time gave him the confidence to write from his heart and produce himself.  It's that confidence that carries the day.  Just over a year later he undertook a disastrous tour, and his confidence took a great hit, which, along with being successfully sued for copywrite infringement for My Sweet Lord, took a lot out him.  It wouldn't be until 1979's \\"George Harrison\\" that he would put out another collection that would rival this in quality.<br /><br />Despite (or maybe, Because of) Harrison's confidence, it is a flawed album.  A co-producer might have been wise, as some songs need some help.  The band is good, obviously, but the arrangements seem to lack inspiration, and the sound is somewhat flat.<br /><br />Which brings us to the release.  No doubt overdue, I am somewhat disappointed with the sound.  It just doesn't sound like a huge upgrade over the 1990 version.  Maybe it just wasn't there in the original master, in which case they should have done a remix from the multitracks.  It still sounds pretty flat.<br /><br />Also, as with Brainwashed and bonus disc with the Harrison box, the \\"special edition\\" extra disc does not warrent the extra cost.  It seems that the powers that be know that Harrison fans will shell out for the extras, no matter what.  Instead of piecemealing out the Japanese concerts, why can't they just release a concert DVD?  Irritating to continue to just have teasers from those concerts.<br /><br />At any rate, I am very happy to have a quality reissue of this album.  The packaging is very nice, following the ATMP and Brainwashed \\"box\\" theme.  Very tasteful, very George.  Just wish the sound was better, but don't be misled.  If you're not an audiophile, you will enjoy this release very much. And, if you have the money, you will enjoy the packaging, the Give Me Love 1 song concert video, and the first (authorized) CD release of Deep Blue and Miss O'Dell.<br /><br />That leaves only George's two weakest albums, Dark Horse (hoarse) and Extra Texture that remain to get the re-issue treatment. B000002TQV|5.0|I am definitely a late bloomer to the Radiohead fraternity. I heard the name \\"Fake Plastic Trees\\" and knew it was considered one of the better Radiohead songs, but never heard or just didn't remember it. Street Spirit is a mesmerizing song, amazing, haunting, chilling, but in the end it's a triumphant and uplifting song with the closing lyrics of both the song and the album being a heartfelt positive final thought \\"Immerse yourself in love\\".    What a great album, If I had a gun to my head and had to pick a favorite Radiohead CD as a relatively new listener, I would choose \\"OK Computer\\" but not by much.    \\"The Bends\\" is the sheer, purely beautiful and melodic Radiohead whereas \\"OK Computer\\" is the brilliant, fully realized monolith of a CD that they may never top.    I am so glad I finally gave these guys a chance, my life will be forever changed because of it.    I am now a true and eternal fan.

B000G0O5N2|4.0|Forget the previous review  bashing this disc for using Mpeg2. It was written by an obvious HD DVD zealot who knows not of which he speaks. Just about every professional reviewer that has seen this disc has given it high marks for picture quality, and I concur. There is no DVD player or upscaler in the world that will match this Blu-ray disc in picture quality, and that doesn't even take into account the excellent, uncompressed Linear PCM soundtrack! Superb! Forget about VC-1. Why does everybody want to squeeze everything down into the smallest space possible and throw information away? Because that is what the VC-1 codec does. Can it look good? Sure it can, but so can Mpeg2 - and this Mpeg2, mind you, is not the same 'old' Mpeg2, this is a new version of Mpeg2 with new extensions for authoring HD content.<br /><br />On a 50GB dual-layered Blu-ray disc such as this (HD DVD maxes out at 30GB, by the way), high bitrate Mpeg2 transfers can be and often are excellent, and quite transparent. This transfer looks completely natural. There are no compression artifacts apparent, film grain is true, and real, colours are natural, the blacks are deep and shadow detail is superb.<br /><br />So forget about what video codec is being used (Blu-ray can use Mpeg2, H.264/AVC or VC-1), don't let anyone try to convince you of the  'inferiority of Blu-ray and Mpeg2 ', and enjoy this excellent film on this superior high definition disc format.<br /><br />One other note, Amazon incorrectly lists Vin Diesel and Samuel L. Jackson as starring in this film. They are not in this film. I think they may have mixed up the credits with the film Pitch Black.

B000GYI32M|5.0|Okay, so season three of my favorite primetime soap opera, The O.C., wasn't nearly up to snuff with the spectacular first season and the slightly less spectacular second season. But, despite that, I still tuned in every Thursday night and when the DVDs were released, I bought them and relived the season again.<br /><br />While the third season was a bit of a letdown in a number of ways, I will say that a month into the fourth season, The O.C. has regained its form and is shining. It's just too bad that it is up against the two strongest shows on television, CSI and Grey's Anatomy. Despite all that, season four is looking to be the best season since the phenomenal first season.<br /><br />My opinion on why the third season was a bit of a letdown is the fact that creator Josh Schwartz seems to have taken a back seat in this season. He was the one with the vision for the show and its fantastic inaugural season and without him in his prominent position (or so it seems), the show wasn't quite the same.<br /><br />Unfortunately, the show continued to introduce unlikeable characters in the third season, much as they had in the first two seasons. This takes away from the great relationships that make the show so good, the Sandy and Kirsten, Summer and Seth, Ryan and Marissa and Julie and her man of the week, storylines.<br /><br />Season three picked up a short while after the shocking season two finale left off. As we left them, Marissa (Mischa Barton) had just shot Ryan's (Ben McKenzie) brother Trey (guest star Logan Marshall Green) as the two brothers fought. Fearing for Ryan's life, Marissa pulled the trigger just moments before Seth (Adam Brody) and Summer (the absolutely gorgeous Rachel Bilson) walked through the door.<br /><br />Trey had been nothing but trouble since his arrival in Newport Beach in season two. He had betrayed Ryan and the Cohen family, attacked Marissa and gotten into a boatload of trouble. The gunshot didn't kill him, but left him in a coma. Marissa's role in the shooting was questioned, as Julie Cooper (Melinda Clarke), still reeling from the death of her second husband Caleb Nicol at the end of season two, tried to pay off Trey to implicate Ryan and spare Marissa. The ploy didn't work and Trey rode off into the sunset on a Greyhound bus.<br /><br />But, the implications from the shooting lived on, as both Marissa and Ryan were expelled from the Harbor School. While Ryan was readmitted, Marissa spent most of the season at Newport Union, the local public school, where she met even more people that would play a significant role in the rest of the season.<br /><br />The start of the season also found Kirsten (Kelly Rowan) in rehab, where she had been admitted at the end of season two, as Sandy (Peter Gallagher), Ryan and Seth tried to cope with her out of the house. Kirsten met Charlotte (guest star Jeri Ryan) in rehab and she would also play a big role in the early part of the season.<br /><br />The Marissa-Ryan story line again took some strange turns, as has been the case in the first two years. Her banishment to Newport Union found her hanging with new friends, particularly surfer Johnny (guest star Ryan Donowho), which brought out a little jealousy in Ryan. The two were on and off for much of the season, with Marissa hooking up with bad-boy Volchok (guest star Cam Gigandet), a former friend of Johnny's, after Johnny fell off a cliff to his death in front of Marissa, Ryan and Marissa's younger sister Caitlin (guest star and future series regular Willa Holland). His death also led to the introduction of his cousin Sadie (guest star Nikki Reed). Sadie and Ryan had a brief relationship, but his acceptance at college kind of turned things around as she headed off into the sunset. Marissa eventually returns to Harbor, thanks to a little help from an unlikely ally, Taylor Townsend (guest star and future series regular Autumn Reeser, who is Summer's top competition for most beautiful woman on television).<br /><br/>While Marissa was at Newport Union, her mother Julie was searching for a way to get back on her feet. Caleb's will left her with no money and because of that, her attempt to reunite with her former husband and Marissa's dad, Jimmy Cooper (guest star Tate Donovan) failed and Julie was forced to move into a trailer park, while Marissa bunked at Summer's house. Of course Julie wasn't down for long, as she quickly became cozy with Summer's dad Neil (guest star Michael Nouri) and the two became engaged near the end of the season. Julie and Kirsten also started a high end match making business that remains part of the show in season four.<br /><br />With Kirsten in rehab, the management of the Newport Group is left to Sandy and he finds himself caught between his morals and big business as he strives to build a new hospital. Kirsten's return home isn't all roses either, as she brings Charlotte to town and with that comes a whole load of trouble, as she tries to bilk first Kirsten and then Julie, out of money. She ultimately fails and disappears without a trace, thankfully. The hospital deal eats into Sandy's time and causes a lot of stress on his marriage. His decision to back out of the deal at the end of the season shows that he is back to the old Sandy.<br /><br />The core relationship in season three was the Summer-Seth storyline. With college on the horizon, Summer worries that Seth's desire to get as far away from Newport as possible will pull them apart. But, when Summer aces her SATs, much to Seth's surprise, the two apply to Brown together. Seth doesn't get in and not wanting to stop Summer from going, he breaks up with her. Of course, this devastates both of them, and comes to head at prom, where Summer tries to drink away her problems. Seth, determined to win back the love of his life, heads to Brown for student orientation, bound to find a way in. While there, he runs into Anna (guest star Samaire Armstrong), a blast from the first season past. While they can't concoct a plan to get Seth into Brown, Anna finds an alternative in the Rhode Island School of Design, and then proceeds to help Summer and Seth get back together again.<br /><br />As mentioned, this season continued the introduction of characters that just aren't likeable. Volchok and Charlotte come to mind as the two worst offenders. Johnny played the role of Oliver in season one, the person who came between Ryan and Marissa. Thankfully, all the characters were written out of the show at the end of the season or at the beginning of season four.<br /><br />The shocking finale (though it wasn't as shocking as it could've been had Mischa Barton not gone on television and told the world that she was being killed off), brought viewers back to the first season, as Ryan carried Marissa away from the burning car, much like he carried her out of an ally in Tijuana two years earlier. The effects of her death are felt strongly in season four, as the main characters try to carry on without her.<br /><br />This set had some interesting bonus features. The making of the Subways music video was a short piece on the band's appearance on the show. What's in a Name was an interesting feature showing how Josh Schwartz uses people he knows and staffers on the show to name characters on the show. There is a solid gag reel, a making of an episode featurette and an interesting take on commentary. Viewers listen to Schwartz and other staff members talk about certain scenes in two different episodes. It's not one whole episode of commentary, but it is still interesting to hear some behind the scenes stuff.<br /><br />While the show itself hit a bump in the road during season three, the DVD set was well done and the packaging was significantly better than that for season two. Now if only the ratings would pick up for an excellent season four, things would be all good in The O.C.ision). <br /> <br />While Marissa was at Newport Union, her mother Julie was searching for a way to get back on her feet. Caleb's will left her with no money and because of that, her attempt to reunite with her former husband and Marissa's dad, Jimmy Cooper (guest star Tate Donovan) failed and Julie was forced to move into a trailer park, while Marissa bunked at Summer's house. Of course Julie wasn't down for long, as she quickly became cozy with Summer's dad Neil (guest star Michael Nouri) and the two became engaged near the end of the season. Julie and Kirsten also started a high end match making business that remains part of the show in season four. <br /> <br />With Kirsten in rehab, the management of the Newport Group is left to Sandy and he finds himself caught between his morals and big business as he strives to build a new hospital. Kirsten's return home isn't all roses either, as she brings Charlotte to town and with that comes a whole load of trouble, as she tries to bilk first Kirsten and then Julie, out of money. She ultimately fails and disappears without a trace, thankfully. The hospital deal eats into Sandy's time and causes a lot of stress on his marriage. His decision to back out of the deal at the end of the season shows that he is back to the old Sandy.  <br /> <br />The core relationship in season three was the Summer-Seth storyline. With college on the horizon, Summer worries that Seth's desire to get as far away from Newport as possible will pull them apart. But, when Summer aces her SATs, much to Seth's surprise, the two apply to Brown together. Seth doesn't get in and not wanting to stop Summer from going, he breaks up with her. Of course, this devastates both of them, and comes to head at prom, where Summer tries to drink away her problems. Seth, determined to win back the love of his life, heads to Brown for student orientation, bound to find a way in. While there, he runs into Anna (guest star Samaire Armstrong), a blast from the first season past. While they can't concoct a plan to get Seth into Brown, Anna finds an alternative in the Rhode Island School of Design, and then proceeds to help Summer and Seth get back together again. <br /> <br />As mentioned, this season continued the introduction of characters that just aren't likeable. Volchok and Charlotte come to mind as the two worst offenders. Johnny played the role of Oliver in season one, the person who came between Ryan and Marissa. Thankfully, all the characters were written out of the show at the end of the season or at the beginning of season four. <br /> <br />The shocking finale (though it wasn't as shocking as it could've been had Mischa Barton not gone on television and told the world that she was being killed off), brought viewers back to the first season, as Ryan carried Marissa away from the burning car, much like he carried her out of an ally in Tijuana two years earlier. The effects of her death are felt strongly in season four, as the main characters try to carry on without her. <br /> <br />This set had some interesting bonus features. The making of the Subways music video was a short piece on the band's appearance on the show. What's in a Name was an interesting feature showing how Josh Schwartz uses people he knows and staffers on the show to name characters on the show. There is a solid gag reel, a making of an episode featurette and an interesting take on commentary. Viewers listen to Schwartz and other staff members talk about certain scenes in two different episodes. It's not one whole episode of commentary, but it is still interesting to hear some behind the scenes stuff. <br /> <br />While the show itself hit a bump in the road during season three, the DVD set was well done and the packaging was significantly better than that for season two. Now if only the ratings would pick up for an excellent season four, things would be all good in The O.C.

B000J3EEBY|5.0|\\"This record is a little like equipping yourself with a Eurail card.  It's like saying, `I don't know where I'm going to go to on this trip. I'm just going to get on board the train, and allow each encounter to lead to the next.'\\"  So says Loreena McKennitt at her website, regarding her release \\"An Ancient Muse.\\"  Although gone from the recording studio for nine years, she shows that her clear, clean, beautiful voice has not suffered in the meantime.  Her \\"train trip\\" takes us back to the Middle East, for the most part, to explore the instruments, sounds and melodies of that area of the world, one that she has devoted to much study.  A side trip or two is in order (\\"The English Ladye And The Knight,\\" lyrics by Sir Walter Scott; \\"Penelope's Song\\" from Greece), but in all directions Loreena leads to unexpected places and auditory pleasures in her latest CD.  It's one of her best, and definitely worth adding to your collection.

B000FBGBPC|5.0|The sophomore slump...it's a fate no band in the world wants to encounter after making a debut album that hits hard and sells millions of copies. Three Days Grace managed to capture the ears of millions of fans with their stomping hit single \\"I Hate Everything About You\\" and its follow-up crunchy anthem \\"Just Like You\\". While some may have dismissed the band as the \\"here today/gone tomorrow\\" variety, Three Days Grace were out to prove the critics wrong. Three Days Grace should silence all of its detractors with ONE-X, which proves to be a most satisfying listen from front to back. While they do intregrate some seriously melodic moments within the scope of these twelve tracks, they also inject some serious punch into their sonic assault. <br />Take for instance the first single, \\"Animal I Have Become\\", which is a seriously catchy alt-metal nugget with a sinister riff and a catchy beat, while the vocals hit home on a song about escaping the dark side you can't control. Indeed, a lot of the themes on the album address alienation, bad relationships, loneliness, but there's also some uplift in not only the words, as the title tracks' lyrics convey, but some serious shine to the music. \\"Pain\\", while slightly soft in the beginning, kicks into gear for a seriously crunchy gem that rocks as hard as anything else in this day and age. The melodic parts start to come into the forefront on the semi-acoustic \\"Never Too Late\\" and the lush title track, but on tracks like the old school metal of \\"Riot!\\", 3DG seriously will get you not only pumping your fist, but banging your head as well.  <br />ONE-X is a step forward for Three Days Grace, and a wake-up call to anyone who thinks that alternative metal is dying...on the contrary, thanks to bands like Three Days Grace and albums like ONE-X, alt-metal is reinvigorated, alive, and breathing better than ever.

B00005JPAM|4.0|In spite of my initial lack of interest in the subject matter, \\"The Queen\\" is a compelling, soundly character-driven movie. Many of the events are necessarily fictionalized (understandably, no one in the royal family has publicly spoken of this time), but regardless of its literal accuracy, you really feel like you were there when it all happened - like you're peering into a secret world.<br /><br />There's a strong emotional spine at the center of it - a public family struggling to reconcile their private grief with a very public one. It's a unique situation where age-old protocols are useless, and the royals have to make things up as they go along. Even if we can't directly empathize with this, Mr. Frears gives it an emotion that's clear and powerful.<br /><br />The performances are uniformly excellent.  As it should be, any weaknesses in the actors' resemblance to their real-life counterparts is made a moot point.<br /><br />Though well-paced, this is a film about restraint, and as such, may require a bit more patience.  Audiences who can accommodate a quieter piece will be richly rewarded.

They're smarter than you think.<br /><br />I found the ending rather predictable (I was sure what would happen, but I just didn't know exactly how it would happen), but I won't spoil it for anyone who hasn't yet seen the movie.<br /><br />So, three stars for a decent morality play and some mind bogglingly beautiful animation, and a tribute to motoring history. B00000JPYQ|5.0|UFO typified the best elements of hard rock, but often came across as generic and derivative. B000JBXXZ4|4.0|First off, let me say I'm really surprised to see this album get such mixed reviews, although most are extremely positive. But if you know this band at all, what you DON'T do is go buy their latest album EXPECTING a certain sound.  If you do, you probably will be let down.  Incubus is not cookie-cutter design group.  They are far too smart and a large pool of talent to stick to the same sound. <br /> <br />They will always reinvent themselves, keep it fresh and find a way to be creative.  And you just have to love that about a band in an age where everybody pretty much sounds the same.  Who sounds like these boys???  Nobody...ever has or ever will. <br /> <br />Alright, now that I've got the rant out of my system, onto Light Grenades! <br /> <br />I'm a huge fan of this album.  Like its predecessors, the first listen was a warm up, and I recognized that yet again...\\"this is different for Incubus.\\"  Many thought ACLOTM was a let down, I'm still baffled by this.  Next to SCIENCE, it's my favorite album.  But this cd is outstanding work, and is right up there with those two. Music wise, how can you complain with Mike playing the axe.  The man is brilliant, and he again and again impresses me.  The rest of the band is in full force as well, although I'm still listening for Kilmore on the records more.  But he does a lot more than just 1's and 2's now. And this album seems to be the most personal of all writings by Brandon...which adds to its power. <br /> <br />Summary of tracks <br /> <br />1. Quicksand -  \\"Ok...the monster is awake...\\" Just an intro track...but it does its job.  It sets the mood and tone for the whole cd.  \\"Some people fall in love and touch the sky, some people fallin love and find quicksand.\\"  You can tell Brandon has some heartbreak to share this time around. <br /> <br />2. A Kiss to Send Us Off - My favorite easily so far. A melodic riff comes in that is addicting and is followed by some classic Incubus grunge.  As the album seems to revolve around the subject of love, this song hits home for me as I feel it will for many.  \\"Just one...more...tongue...kiss before the sky it falls...out...from...this cloud we're hovering on.\\"  Painfully beautiful <br /> <br />3. Dig - A well chosen single to follow Anna Molly.  This song will gain many new Incubus fans, and will rub long-standing fans in a special way.  Like Quicksand, this song lets you know that Incubus has evolved yet again in the best of ways.  \\"We all have something that digs at us...at least we dig each other.\\"  Very poignant lyrics.  This song feels to me an anthem for best friends, and Brandon talks of camraderie being the message.  This will be a favorite to many. <br /> <br />4. Anna Molly - The first single, and for good reason.  Full of energy, speed and emotion.  There is a longing in Brandon's vocals that speaks volumes, while the lyrics are left to much interpretation.  Fans that have trouble adjusting to the band continually evolving their sound will cling to this song a while until they finally open up.  <br /> <br />5. Love Hurts - A great ballad.  Many reviews find this to be the low-point of the album, but across the board I've found it be a personal favorite to many.  A very simple song lyrics wise...\\"without love, I won't survive.\\"  A song purely about love, how it can be a blessing and a curse.  In this aspect, I don't see how it couldn't be a fan favorite cause almost anybody can relate to it. <br /> <br />6. Light Grenades - I love this song, and almost feel it would've been a better first single.  It has the same ability as Anna Molly to grab old-school fans and make them excited for the album, but if I hadn't heard much Incubus and heard this song on the radio I would be instantly obsessed with the band!  Going back to the days of SCIENCE, this song has an infectious groove, is urgent and its pace is so much fun to keep up with.  Brandon has fun with his lyrics, and you can tell.  Defintely one of my favorites. <br /> <br />7. Earth to Bella pt. 1 - I love how these guys pick the right time to slow things down, let you settle after such an energetic song and come back down to earth.  Ahhh but the best part?  It doesn't stay soft for long, when Mike comes crashing in with some thrashing guitar work while Brandon proclaims \\"I'm ok to sink...\\"  A short but sweet song, and a great seguay to the next track. <br /> <br />8. Oil and Water - This song really impressed me lyrics wise.  It's hard to resist a song that is so relative lyrically.  The rhythm and tone of the song takes me back to Morning View, Mike and Jose really do a great job here.  \\"Babe, this wouldn't be the first time, and will not be the last time...there is no parasol that could shelter these weathers.\\"   <br /> <br />9. Diamonds and Coal - If I were forced to pick a least favorite track, personally I guess it would be this one.  I love the song, and the aformentioned opinion will most likely vanish in a week.  At first it comes off too simple and redundant.  But once you get the message of the song, you realize the importance of repeating the title.  \\"In spite of this, we're doing just fine, even diamonds start as coal. Give us time to shine, even diamonds start as coal.\\"   <br /> <br />10. Rogues - This one to me took a page from ACLOTM, which is a wonderful page to take from to me.  The guitars are infectious, drums are tight and kicking.  \\"Hats off and applause to rogues and evolution! The ripple effect is too good not to mention. If you're not affected then you're not paying attention!\\" Mike busts out a killer, funky solo which will make many fans smile. <br /> <br />11. Paper Shoes - A wonderful song, again a little different for Incubus, which is why I love it. \\"You're about as reliable as paper shoes in bad weathers, but the pain will roll off water on feathers.\\"  Very melodic, and the drums are superb. <br /> <br />12. Pendulous Threads - An earlier reviewer wrote something I agree with on a certain level.  I feel this should've been the end track, cause this song packs some punch.  I love Earth to Bella pt. 2, but I would've pulled a switcheroo with the two tracks.  It doesn't take anything away from either song however.  Next to track 2, as of now this is tops in my book.  Mike gets in your face with some sharp guitar work, and builds to the bridge.  This is another song that harkens back to ACLOTM and SCIENCE simultaneously.  The drums and bass are intense, and if the band is as smart as I think they are, they will HAVE to play this song live cause the energy is undeniable. It would have been the perfect ending to this album, just like it had the perfect beginning. <br /> <br />13. Earth to Bella pt. 2 - I love this song, its just a note I wouldn't end an album on.  \\"Don't you want to see the deep, it's not that hard...\\" Still a great song, indeed. <br /> <br />Any true Incubus fan just has to show a lot of respect for this album, while it has some sounds from past works, it is still amazingly fresh and different for the band. Just really listen to it, the entire way through...more than just once or twice.    <br /> <br />Outstanding songs - A Kiss to Send Us Off, Dig, Light Grenades, Rogues, Pendulous Threads <br /> <br />\\"Sleeper\\" songs (songs that you will end up loving the more you listen) - Love Hurts, Earth to Bella 1+2, Oil and Water, Paper Shoes <br /> <br />I gave 4/5 stars cause I couldn't give 4.5...which is what I really feel.

B000JK8OYU|5.0|I'm not a hard core beatles fan as many of the people reviewing here but I am a fan. From a younger persons perspective I would say that \\"Love\\" is much more appealing then the current CD issues of Beatles albums. Those having grown up when the Beatles actually existed and listening to vinyl might be used to less then perfect clarity in recordings and Im sure some would say that its 'its the way the songs should be heard' but these new releases sound great, the continuous mix is a great way to listen to some of the Beatles best tracks.  <br /> <br />As good as this band may be their staple fans are getting older, and it's not a bad idea to update their sound slighty, as long as its done in the right way - as it has been here. This is as good a 'new' album as your likely to get. If nothing slightly 'new' were ever released where do you think the beatles music would be in 50 years? It may be timeless but nobody can say where music will head and given the current state of things it isnt promising. At worst this album will annoy some old fans, at best it will make new people appreciate the great music of the Beatles.
B000062X90|2.0|I was tipped off to Wishbone Ash from an article I read about Steve Harris (Iron Maiden) who credited this band as being one of his earliest and biggest influences.    I bought their self titled debut album and this one from Amazon based on that article and also because both of these albums were well received by reviewers.    Maybe I read too much into the article or perhaps this was just another spur of the moment purchase, but I think these albums would better suit 1970's rock fans per se i.e. a fan of the period than those who prefer the harder style of rock that would emerge from the mid to late 1970's.    The album does have its moments, and there are some really nice melodies and some nice guitar/bass work, but it too often drifts into that very early \\"happy happy\\" 1970's sound that marked the transition from the 1960s to the 1970's.    I guess that should be expected, since this album was released only two years into the turbulent new decade at the close of the flower power hippie period.    The use of the twin guitars a noteworthy feature, since this band is also credited as an early pioneer of this style of rock.  The bass is unusually active for this period and doesn't just settle for simple changes, which would make sense, since they did influence Steve Harris after all.    I prefer this album to their debut, but it does make me think of an English version of the Eagles if there ever was such a thing.  Not that that is a bad thing.    I am a fan of 1970's rock and I think this decade produced some fantastic guitar/bass rock, but this is just a little too 70's for my tastes.    If you are new to Wishbone Ash as I am, but are basically a hard rock/metal fan at heart, try looking for MP3 versions on the web and just test drive one or two songs before you decide on buying a complete album.

And with there being so much publicity, there will most certainly be plenty of newcomers.  Okay. (I've been all over it since release date and I'm still finding something new with each listen). It's a front to back album that will require no skipping.   <br /> <br />If you aint heard it by now, then you must drop what you're doing right this minute and RUN to pick it up.  You can thank me later.

One of the best, nicest things I've seen anywhere in ages. Bravo. Bravo! BRAVO!!

B000002TYX|5.0|Of the three Beatles Anthology volumes, this first one is easily the most exciting for Beatles fans and collectors. We are treated to five selections from the Beatles' Decca Audition.  Even if it wasn't the greatest tape the Beatles could've made, I'm sure Decca is stil kicking themselves now for not signing the Beatles!   <br /> <br />It gets better and better as time goes by.  The Beatles sang \\"I'll Get You\\" at the London Palladium in 1963, and \\"All My Loving\\" on Ed Sullivan in 1964.  Both of those recordings are presented here.  Other highlights include: <br /> <br />*One After 909 - I actually prefer this version to the one that got released in 1970. <br />*Eight Days a Week - the tight harmony at the beginning works well.  Also the false starts were interesting. <br />*How Do You Do It - the unreleased single. <br />*Free As A Bird - a new Beatles masterpiece. <br /> <br />Die-hard Beatles fans will not be disappointed with this set!

0375836675|5.0|Markus Zusak might be my favorite author now, and I've read a lot of books by a lot of authors. I have not, however, read three books of such magnitude by the same author. Upon completing GETTING THE GIRL, THE BOOK THIEF, and now I AM THE MESSENGER, I sit back in awe at the mastery of the writing, the power of the message, the truth of such stories.<br /><br />Winner of the 2003 Children's Book Council of Australia's Book of the Year Award and nominated for best young adult book at the 2006 L.A. Times Festival of Books, I AM THE MESSENGER (or THE MESSENGER in Australia) tells the story of Ed Kennedy, nineteen-year-old taxi cab driver and all-around average guy. In fact, he's the epitome of average -- faithful friends, stinky dog, dead-end job, and girl who loves someone else.<br /><br />That's why it's such a big deal for Ed, Marv, and Ritchie to get trapped in a bank during a stickup. One of the thieves gets spooked, drops his gun, and somehow Ed ends up with the weapon and the town's praise. That might be a winning hand for Ed if he doesn't receive the first mysterious playing card, the Ace of Diamonds in his mailbox. It's a card with a message for him to deliver. Or else.<br /><br />Messages like Ed's will change a person, if he or she lets them. That's the beauty of Zusak's story. Ed discovers the changing power in simple, personalized messages of love, even if they're ones he's forced to deliver. While I could imagine a cynical reader calling Ed's 12 messages a tad forced, I would differ with them on every case. Ed's stories are simple proof that if a \\"guy like him can stand up and do what he did, then maybe everyone can. Maybe everyone can live beyond what they're capable of.\\"<br /><br />-- Reviewed by Jonathan Stephens

B000000H66|5.0|First off, this is an album littered with marked contrasts. It is extremely melodic and engaging, yet relentlessly heavy and brutal. It is punctuated with Chuck's screaming, deranged and highly idiosyncratic vocal style, yet possesses many moments of rare and extreme beauty, like the ending to the final track, or the lilting acoustic guitar that appears at the end of 'Crystal Mountain'. The songs are for the most part highly concise and markedly well composed, trimmed of any excess and delivered to perfection, and as such manage to be accessible and enjoyable even on a first listen, despite the striking fact that each is technical and intricate to an extreme degree: the music is defined by numerous time changes, shrieking, schizophrenic riffs which interlock and contrast with each other, subtle rhythmic shifts, powerful dynamics, ultra-complex, groove infused drumming, and striking, endearing chorus sections.<br /><br />The wealth of contrasts, however, does little to detract from the undoubted enjoyable nature of _Symbolic_. It is actually an album which is ruthlessly innovative and highly daring, fusing brutal, technical death metal with more progressive aspects, a tightened melodic sensibility and songwriting which I believe has never been bettered in the genre. Witness the stellar, breathtaking riff which opens the title track, the oh-so welcome release of tension which propels the ingenious chorus of 'Empty Words', the delicious interplay between bass and drums which underpins the intro to 'Sacred Serenity' (and lays bare the fundamental dynamics which drive the music under all the spectacular guitar playing), the epic, unpredictable twists of 'Perennial Quest', not to mention the blistering, space age thrash exemplified by the melodic '1000 Eyes' or 'Without Judgement'.<br /><br />The intelligence in the compositions is mirrored by the intriguing nature of the lyrics-highly cryptic as always, but by now light years away from blood and gore death metal fodder. Chuck seems to tackle images, manipulation, discovery and perception, and each is covered well, providing a base which allows these cerebral and intricate pieces to flourish. The level of sophistication and abstraction is high, no doubt, but the spine-tingling, kinetic nature of the songs keeps everything exciting: this is heavy, brutal music of neck snapping intensity which is primal, engaging and fulfilling, all at once.<br /><br />A remarkable and important statement from this landmark band, the sheer power and lack of compromise which exemplified Chuck Schulinder's work cannot be overlooked. It stands right at the pinnacle of metal albums as a whole, and the fact the Chuck would go on to push boundaries right to breaking point with _The Sound of Perseverance_ is genuinely frightening. I am thankful that he created this truly exceptional musical legacy and shared it with us all before he left us.ck seems to tackle images, manipulation, discovery and perception, and each is covered well, providing a base which allows these cerebral and intricate pieces to flourish. The level of sophistication and abstraction is high, no doubt, but the spine-tingling, kinetic nature of the songs keeps everything exciting: this is heavy, brutal music of neck snapping intensity which is primal, engaging and fulfilling, all at once. <br />A remarkable and important statement from this landmark band, the sheer power and lack of compromise which exemplified Chuck Schulinder's work cannot be overlooked. It stands right at the pinnacle of metal albums as a whole, and the fact the Chuck would go on to push boundaries right to breaking point with _The Sound of Perseverance_ is genuinely frightening. I am thankful that he created this truly exceptional musical legacy and shared it with us all before he left us.

0131103628|5.0|If the original syntax of C was both pith and precise, then the spirit of the text follows the spirit of the language perfectly.  It is remarkably short, provides a clear sense of not only how to program well and how to structure large tasks intelligently but also a very intelligent presentation of how the computer executes the generated code and what is actually going on under the hood.  This last aspect is sufficiently lost in 4G languages and elaborate frameworks and tools that the critical art of debugging has become a crass exertise and \\"tweak and test\\" that lacks a deep appreciation for why some things weren't a good idea to start with.   <br /> <br />No mater what language you program in, please read K&R.  It will be one of the few programming books you will still own ten years later (my current copy was bought in 1981).
B000AGTPUK|3.0|As a book, the Polar Express is a modern Christmas classic.  I was both ecstactic and sceptical to hear it would be turned into a feature film. Yet the team behind this guaranteed that care would be given to the treatment of the material. <br /> <br />Care is given to the material.  The world of the film is true to the world of the book. The theme is that of innocence, and if you're looking for a film that encapsulates innocence, look no further.  Zemekis and crew do a fantastic job of illustrating the innocence of children at Chrismastime.  This film has a lot of spirit going for it.  And by far, it is the most innocent, 100% kid friendly movie I've seen in recent memory. <br /> <br />The filmmakers take some liberties.  Notably in adding some conflict, such as difficulties in reaching the North Pole, creating some side characters, and adding more depth to the North Pole that is featured ever so briefly in the book.  The best addition is easily the homeless man who appears only to the Hero boy on top of the train.  The worst has to be some awkward decisions about the North Pole.  Sorry, but the ultra futuristic look and Santa's rainbow whip kinda turned me off. <br /> <br />Then there is the design.  This movie looks specatacular - in 3D.  And if you see this in Imax 3D, it is a breathtaking experience.  However, on DVD the 3D experience is not there to reveal the film's many shortcomings.  For one, \\"oohs\\" and \\"ahs\\" of the 3D experience are replaced with the filmmakers attempts to stretch the story into a 100 minute feature.  Furthermore, the supposedly groundbreaking \\"acting\\" in the film makes the people's movements seem awkward.  While the actual character designs are fine (though I would probably reconsider some of the facial expressions in the film), the movements do not allow you to suspend yourself in disbelief.  The final blow is the film's music.  The score is fine, which seems to recall Silversti's own Back to the Future, while also recalling another winter based score, Danny Elfman's score to Edward Scissorhands.  Sadly, the same can't be said for the film's songs, which lack the immediacy and poignancy of Disney's animated features. <br /> <br />Overall, the Polar Express is a great family film that fares better on the big screen than on the small one.  On the small screen, the story moves slowly and the visuals don't come to life nearly as well as they do on the huge Imax screen.  Zemekis and all involved capture the innocence of the book perfectly, but can't stretch the theme of the story to keep us sustained for 100 minutes.  Catch it at the Imax in 3D or read the book.  As a stand alone film at home, it may be a snoozer.

B000JJRIN4|4.0|First off, if you're expecting music as featured on her first solo album 'Love, Angel, Music, Baby', you may be dissapointed. There are a few pop songs on here, such as 'The Sweet Escape' that reminds me a bit of Madonna's 'True Blue' in its retro sound and the sort of pop ballad 'Wonderful Life'. Other than that, Gwen goes for songs that actually sound as if they could be covered by No Doubt.<br /><br />The best song on the album in my opinion is the Nelle Hopper penned-track '4 in the Morning'.  A nice pop/r&b groove love ballad that will have you hooked and singing along by the second chorus. Also, another fan favorite seems to be 'Early Winter' which is surprisingly another ballad that reminds me of No Doubt's 'Simple Kind of Life.'<br /><br />Gwen also has some rather pop/rap-ish songs where she really delivers some tongue-twisting lyrics that she's known for now. 'Breaking Up' may lead you to believe its a ballad about lost love but instead it's a rap about trying to get a message through to someone while dealing with the call being dropped on the cell phone. 'Don't Get It Twisted' plays on the circus music theme but gets into another rap. Heavy on the Neptune's beats and unique sounds are 'Wind it Up' which samples a song from the musical \\"The Sound of Music\\" and the rather original song 'Yummy.' A rather fun R&B/Hip-Hop song 'Orange County Girl' also sets the tone of this album being very different from her first solo effort.<br /><br />Now, for the weakness. It sounds like some of these songs are more B-Side-ish than they are new, fresh, album-ready material. 'U Started It' and 'Flourescent' are okay, but forgettable tracks that get lost in the fold. While 'Wonderful Life' is interesting, it also gets lost when stacked up against the other pop ballads and experimental tracks. While her first solo effort seemed to be consistent and well thought out, at first listen, this just seems weak and rushed in comparison. Yeah, the songs are still good but there are definitely more tracks on this that are skip-worthy than on her first CD. Also, she does best (solo wise) when she's doing pop songs rather than when she's trying to be a Hip-Hop/R&B artist. 12 tracks seems to be a little weak as well ... for those fans who've been following the album development, there's no 'Candyland' on the album at all. B000IU3XU6|5.0|While it is true that this recording (Awake) represents some new directions and selections from Josh Groban, I contend that you really have to get the \\"big picture\\" or the full spectrum of Josh's recordings and performing career in order to fully appreciate his musical repertoire. Once again, we owe much of his success as a vocalist, performer and producer of CD recordings to the guidance of his mentor, David Foster. I think that if Josh had never hooked-up with Foster, his career would not have sky-rocketed as quickly, but we can only theorize on that possibility. The fact remains that Josh's instructor at Interlochen (The National Music Camp in Ann Arbor, Michigan), knew David Foster and forwarded Josh's tape to him to listen to... \\"the rest is history,\\" as they say, and David knew right away that Josh was to be a sudden vocal sensation. David Foster's arrangements have contributed to many solo artists in a similar fashion including Barbra Streisand (the Broadway Album series), Lara Fabian (who also did his recording, Broken Vow), Natalie Cole on \\"My Grownup Christmas List\\" from The David Foster Christmas CD, and most recently, Andrea Bocelli (Under The Desert Sky concert and DVD+CD) as David's interest is to bring Bocelli into the American popular music venue, a slight departure from his classical and Italian popular works.<br /><br />I disagree that this recording (Awake) is the \\"definitive\\" Josh Groban CD recording of his career to date, but rather would say that it would be worthwhile to have all of his recordings and DVDs to really get the total picture (which I do, by the way). I first heard a selection of Josh Groban from his first CD while browsing at a book store, I immediately went back into the CD music section to find out who was singing and purchased the Josh Groban CD. When I asked around, it seemed that no one had ever heard of him, yet! But, within a short time, his follow-up CD+DVD package, Josh Groban In Concert was the recording from his PBS Special concert which finally brought him into the limelight, not to forget his duet with Charlotte Church on The Prayer and Somewhere on her Enchantment DVD (her concert in her hometown of Cardiff, Wales), his duets with Lara and Barbra, his vocal on Remember Me (from the movie soundtrack Troy) and his track of Mi Mancherai (also in the movie: Lady in the Water and Il Postino) from his album Closer, and other collaborations with Lucia Micarelli (on violin) and the musical group, The Corrs. Invariably, the American audience would latch onto his English recordings more readily than those in Italian, (which is exactly the same reason why David Foster convinced Bocelli to address the same venue of popular American music).<br /><br />Awake represents more of a musical departure, and self-direction and production from Josh (including his vocals and drumming on a few tracks), but I would strongly suggest that one should just get all of his recordings to really fully appreciate his talent and direction. I'm just hoping that this is not just another rise to fame, too fast, and then crash and burn (by comparison to Russell Watson who came out with a few CDs and one DVD concert. But Russell didn't have David Foster producing him... Josh did!).<br /><br />In light of Josh's total musicianship, I also think he should explore some cover work as he is also quite gifted as a keyboardist, drummer, etc. I believe he could do a better job at the Great American Sougbook than, let's say, Rod Stewart who really doesn't have the right voice for slow standards. Josh does.  And since his concert ticket prices are quite high, I would rather spend my money on his recorded media to enjoy over and over again, rather than seeing him live one time.<br /><br />In summation, anything Josh does gets my vote of 5 Stars!!!pecial concert which finally brought him into the limelight, not to forget his duet with Charlotte Church on The Prayer and Somewhere on her Enchantment DVD (her concert in her hometown of Cardiff, Wales), his duets with Lara and Barbra, his vocal on Remember Me (from the movie soundtrack Troy) and his track of Mi Mancherai (also in the movie: Lady in the Water and Il Postino) from his album Closer, and other collaborations with Lucia Micarelli (on violin) and the musical group, The Corrs. Invariably, the American audience would latch onto his English recordings more readily than those in Italian, (which is exactly the same reason why David Foster convinced Bocelli to address the same venue of popular American music). <br /> <br />Awake represents more of a musical departure, and self-direction and production from Josh (including his vocals and drumming on a few tracks), but I would strongly suggest that one should just get all of his recordings to really fully appreciate his talent and direction. I'm just hoping that this is not just another rise to fame, too fast, and then crash and burn (by comparison to Russell Watson who came out with a few CDs and one DVD concert. Josh did!). <br /> <br />In light of Josh's total musicianship, I also think he should explore some cover work as he is also quite gifted as a keyboardist, drummer, etc. I believe he could do a better job at the Great American Sougbook than, let's say, Rod Stewart who really doesn't have the right voice for slow standards. 0689853637|5.0|I have several of Sabuda's wonderful Pop-Up books and each are exceptional in their own way.The only way to describe these books is by using words like,magical,romantic,fantastic,mythical,whimiscal,imaginary,curious,intricate,elegant and similar words that convey the imagination and skill Sabuda uses to conceive scenes then make them pop-up in a book as the pages are turned to unfold them.<br /><br />  Being winter scenes, he uses a lot of white, and covers it with glitter to give the effect of new-fallen snow on a cold winter's day.He also makes use of silver papers combined with colors to create magical scenes.<br /><br /> On first opening the book, we are startled by a Snowy Owl that seems to fly right off the page;and with the simple opening of a flap we find a family of mice greeting the day.Next we find a pair of foxes ,in their white winter coats sitting in their den ,and on the same page,with a simple flip appears a rabbit, also in his winter garb.Then a wonderful scene of a Polar bear and fish in glittering,ice cold water. Then we are treated to a scene of leaping bears and playful squirrels;followed by an elegant moose and a pair of beavers.And for a grand finale we have a wonderful,colorful forest,complete with animals ,snowman and friendly little house,and with the pull of a tab,the festive spirit comes alive with 12 flashing colored light.<br /><br /> The only thing,to me at least,that is more intriguing in how these scenes are designed;would be what the scene in the printing shop must be like where these books are printed and assembled.<br /><br /> On other Pop-Up books,I have commented on the fragile hinges these books have; and how prone to cracking and spliting they are. It seems that this problem has beed recognized and in this book a cloth spline and hinges have been incorporated;a positive improvement.

B0000009SY|5.0|I have been a Zappa fan since I snuck a listen to Apostrophe/Over-nite Sensation from my Dad's collection 20 years ago.  Like much of Zappa's music, this album, perhaps his finest overall work, can be oversimplified and categorized ascetically (as a previous reviewer attempted to do). <br /> <br />This is not just \\"silly and crude humor music\\" and it does not fall into a \\"1,2,3,4 category\\" of Zappa listener.  Joe's Garage, as a complete work, attacks and obliterates those individuals/organizations who, through various means of censorship, insidiously undermine the purpose of creating music. <br /> <br />He accomplishes this with direct attacks on the political right (e.g. the Central Scrutinizer), conservative religious parties (e.g. Catholic Girls), the media and all other pseudo-intellectuals (e.g. packed goose), and, really, anyone whose sensibilities would lead them to censorship of creativity.  Consider the historical context here: the attack on music throughout the 1980's/Tipper Gore's The Parents Music Resource Center was founded in 1985.  The content of Joe's Garage is intended to offend all these people. <br /> <br />Like all art, one can make a judgment of whether the overall piece appeals to their ascetics, which Joe's Garage does for me - definitely five stars, and leave it at that.  However, true analysis of real art should leave one with questions on intent, message, and composition which Joe's Garage also does very effectively.   <br /> <br />Through this analysis, one can realize one object of Frank Zappa's argument: freedom of expression (in this case music) is important and socially relevant; hence the aforementioned party's desire for censorship.  Beautiful use of irony through music Frank! <br /> <br />\\"Eventually it was discovered that God did not want us to be all the same. This was bad news for the Governments of the World... Mankind must be made more uniformly if THE FUTURE was going to work out... It was about this time that someone came upwith the idea of TOTAL CRIMINALIZATION, based on the principle that if we were ALL crooks we could at least be uniform to some degree in the eyes of the law. Shrewdly our legislators calculated that most people were too lazy to perform a REAL CRIME. So new laws were manufactured making it possible for anyone to violate them at any time of the day or night... which is one of the reasons why music was eventually made ILLEGAL.\\"  <br />--Frank Zappa, liner notes from Joe's Garage, Acts 2

B000H0FEVI|5.0|This is a wonderful and highly original novel about a mentally challenged man named Charlie who wanted to be smart. One day, his wish was granted. A group of scientists selected him for an experimental operation that raised his intelligence to genius level. Suddenly, Charlie found himself transformed, and life, as he knew it, changed.<br /><br />His story is told entirely through Charlie's eyes and perceptions in the form of progress reports. The reader actually sees the change in Charlie take place, as his progress reports become more complex, well written, and filled with the angst of personal discovery and growth, as well as with his gradual awareness of his amazing and accelerated intellectual development.<br /><br />The progress reports are a wonderful contrivance for facilitating the story, and the reader is one with Charlie on his voyage of self-discovery. What happens to Charlie in the long run is profoundly moving and thought provoking. It is no wonder that this author was the recipient of the Nebula Award which is given by the Science Fiction Writers of America for having written the Best Novel of the Year. This is definitely a book well worth reading.
